qas.question: How do most animals use the energy of sunlight?
What do plants use to convert inorganic molecules into carbohydrates, fats, proteins and other biomolecules?
What does photosynthesis convert the energy of sunlight into?
When an animal eats plants or another animal that has eaten plants, what happens to the reduced carbon compounds in the food?

answers.text: become a source of energy and building materials for the animal

qas.question: What happens with the reduced carbon compounds in the food are broken down releasing stored solar energy?

answers.text: giving the animal the energy required for motion

context: Most animals indirectly use the energy of sunlight by <a0_0>eating plants or plant-eating animals<a0_0/>. Most plants use <a1_0>light<a1_0/> to convert inorganic molecules in their environment into carbohydrates, fats, proteins and other biomolecules, characteristically containing reduced carbon in the form of carbon-hydrogen bonds. Starting with carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O), photosynthesis converts the energy of sunlight into <a2_0>chemical energy<a2_0/> in the form of simple sugars (e.g., glucose), with the release of molecular oxygen. These sugars are then used as the building blocks for plant growth, including the production of other biomolecules. When an animal eats plants (or eats other animals which have eaten plants), the reduced carbon compounds in the food <a3_0>become a source of energy and building materials for the animal<a3_0/>. They are either used directly to help the animal grow, or broken down, releasing stored solar energy, and <a4_0>giving the animal the energy required for motion<a4_0/>.
